title: "What is aphasia and how can it affect memory? A case study with Donato and Cornât."
first_phrase: In this excerpt, Donato, a doctor, tries to diagnose Cornât, a patient who is unable to remember his own name. The President suggests testing his memory by having Cornât repeat several names, including his own. However, Cornât cannot remember any of them, causing shock to those present. Donato then tests Cornât's ability to remember numbers, but he still struggles. In the last 200 tokens, we see Donato ask Cornât to count to 10, but he struggles with this task as well. This raises questions about Cornât's memory loss and Donato will continue to investigate whether or not this is caused by aphasia.
content: — Remarquez bien que cette fois il n’y a eu ni mutité, ni aphonie... Est-ce de l’aphasie? Nous allons voir. Le President. — Veuillez lui dire plusieurs noms en terminant par le sien. Nous verrons s’il a complètement perdu la mémoire. Donato. au sujet. — Est-ce Eugène que Ton t’appelle? Cornât. — Non. Donato. — Est-ce Albert? Cornât. —- Non. Donato. — Joseph? Jacques? Auguste? Cornât. — Non. JJnnato. — Est-ce Edouard ? Cornât. — Non. Stupéfaction générale. On sait que le sujet se nomme Edouard. Donato là Cornât).— Répète deux fois à haute voix le chiffre deux. Cornai. — Deux ! deux ! Donato lui passant la main sur le front : — Quel chiffre as-tu dit? Cornât. — Je ne me le rappelle plus. Donato. — Veux-tu bien compter, mon ami, de 1 à 10? Cornât. — Volontiers, (comptant) 1... 3, 4, 5... Donato. — Recommence, tu t’es trompé. Cornât.
last_phrase: In conclusion, losing memory and forgetting specific pieces of information, like numbers, can be a concerning experience. However, techniques like suggestion and counting aloud can be helpful in assessing cognitive function and assisting in memory recovery.
